ZITs - Uh... Hi, Roomie...? / Intro to The List

As I was jumping out of an airplane this weekend, I couldn't help but compare it to the exhilaration I felt the first time that I moved onto campus.  I'd had roommates at camps and stuff before, but I had never actually lived for a long period of time.  It's exciting, but it's also kind of scary.  You don't know what it's going to be like until it happens and everybody has a different experience.  Just like skydiving, right?

First thing you should know is that there are important resources here to help you: your RAs and your RD.  Your RA (Resident Assistant) is a fellow student whose job it is to help you and your roomie work out conflicts and help everybody on the floor get along.  The RD (Residence Director) is your RA's boss, a full time staff person who oversees Residence Hall Communities.  Stay in touch with your RA; he or she is there to help you!

Now, here are some super helpful tips for starting off the year right with your roommate:

    1.  Contact your roommate before move in day!  Hopefully, you have already talked to the person or people you are living with!!  Figure out who is bringing what, how you might want to set up the room, get to know each other a little, and maybe even chat a little bit about your expectations for living together.  Please do this now if you haven't already!!!

    2.  Prepare yourself for living with someone who could be either the complete opposite of you or your long-lost twin.  Either of these possibilities can prove to be wonderful or disastrous or not even relevant.  I can tell you my freshman roommate was my complete opposite.  I was a Music Performance/Education Double Major and he was a Sports Information and Communication Major who was going to be playing on the baseball team.  We laughed at our high school mentalities about a band geek/jock pairing, but it actually turned out very well.  I got him to come see a musical, he got me to watch the World Series, and we ended up learning a lot from each other.

    3.  Be realistic about your expectations for your relationship with your roommate.  Some roomies turn out to be the best friends in the world, and some just don't.  Don't set yourself up to be disappointed.

    4.  Talk to your roommate in person.  Don't be that person who emails and IMs the person who's in the same room as you.  Face to face conversations are the best form of conversation and will actually save a lot of misunderstandings and conflicts.  Here are some things to make sure you talk about:
         Your typical bed time
         Your class schedule (got some early morning classes?)
         Style of studying (with or without music, without distractions, with friends, etc.)
         What is shared and what is not???  This is HUGE!  Make sure your expectations are clear!  (food, clothes, computer, TV, electronic devices, study supplies, etc.)
         Ideal room environment (Frequent guests vs. alone time, hot vs. cold, loud vs. quiet)
         Expectations of visitors (Are there times when guests aren't welcome?  How long can they stay?  etc.)
         How to take care of bills (Cable, micro-fridge rental, etc.)
         Typical pet peeves (for example: "The little IM sounds like 'ba-da-ling!" drive me absolutely crazy!")
         Cleanliness expectations (vacuuming, taking out trash, etc.)

    5.  Address issues early on before they become problems.  You and your roommate will fill out a "Roommate Agreement Form" in which you will address all kinds of different issues so that if a conflict arises later, you can refer back to what you agreed on to help settle the matter.  If there is a problem, don't be afraid to ask your RA to help you.  Don't leave issues unresolved, because you don't want them to affect your academic success, sleeping, stress, or happiness!

Now, the big challenge is always deciding who is bringing what for the room, plus making sure that you have everything that you need for you.  This week's E-vents features a list to make sure you're the most prepared, but before you consult the list, please read:

Zack's Disclaimers About the List



    1. You do not need everything on this list.  Not even close.
    2. Your rooms are not that big, so if you find yourself asking the question, "Will I have enough room for this?" the answer is probably "No."
    3. By the same token, you only have one room.  Everything you have has to fit in that one room.
    4. If you and your roommate can share something, then do so!  Don't waste money and space on something you only need one of.
    5. You will always pack too much.  Pack what you think you need, then go unpack some of it.
    6. Items marked by Flopper ( ) are ones that you definitely don't want to forget (and that you might not have thought of).
    7. Items marked by a Thumbs Down () are items you probably don't need, so, avoid them if possible.  You'll survive.
    8. You really don't need a lot of the stuff on this list.  Seriously.

With that in mind, here is a very comprehensive list of things you might consider bringing with you when you move in to your Residence Hall room.

The List - Bath

Here is a list of items you might want to have related to your own hygiene.  Remember, since you have to share a bathroom with the rest of your floor, all of these items must be stored in your room.

    --Towels
     --Bathrobe - This is totally unnecessary.  Just wear your towel, or your pajamas, or whatever.  Take your clothes with you to the shower if you want to, but you don't need a robe.
    --Bathroom shoes (Flip-Flops) - These are a must for community bathrooms.  (When I was getting ready for college, my mom told me I needed "thongs" for the shower.  She meant flip-flops.  She didn't mean thongs.)
         --Brush/Comb
         --Cosmetics
         --Dental Floss
    --Deodorant
         --Hair dryer
     --Hand Towel - There are paper towels in the bathrooms.  You don't need this.
         --Hand/Body Lotion - The residence halls can get pretty dry, so this isn't a bad idea.
     --Mirror - All residence halls come equipped with mirrors, so this isn't necessary.
    --Nail clippers
         --Razor (and charger if electric)
         --Shampoo & Conditioner
    --Shower caddy - This is another dorm life essential.  Get a nice little caddy to store all your bathroom stuff and it will make life much easier for you.
         --Soap
         --Tissue
         --Toothbrush and toothpaste
         --Washcloths or Loofah or whatever you use to clean your body!
 The List - Medicine Cabinet

It's always a good idea to have a little collection of medicine and things to take care of yourself.  Chances are you won't last a whole year without getting sick.  Tupperware is great for storage!  Here are a few items you might want to include.

         --Acne cream
         --Antacids (Dining Hall food is good, but might take a little adjustment!)
         --Antihistamine
         --Anti-itching lotion/cream
         --Aspirin/Ibuprofen
         --Antibiotic Cream
         --Band-Aids
         --Contact lens solution
         --Cotton balls
         --Cotton swabs
         --Decongestants
         --Eye glasses
         --Eye drops
         --Hot/cold packs
         --Pain reliever
     --Prescription Medication - Don't forget any essentials!!
         --Vapor rub
         --Vitamins
 The List - Bedroom

Not to sound like a broken record, but remember that your bedroom is your whole room.  A lot of the items on this list are luxuries, so remember to balance your wants and needs with what you can afford and what makes the most sense.

    --Alarm clock
     --Answering machine - Don't go out and buy a separate answering machine.  I highly recommend getting a cheap phone that has a built-in answering machine.
     --Area rug - All the rooms are carpeted, so this is a very unnecessary luxury.
   --Bed linens (2 sets)
         --Bed-side lamp - Another luxury, but you can get some pretty cheap "clip-on" reading lamps that are pretty convenient.
         --Blanket or comforter
    --Cinder blocks (4) - Use these to raise your bed to have more room for storage.
         --Clothes hamper - Those collapsible laundry bins work wonders.
         --Corkboard & pushpins - This is a great way to organize your life or display photos.
     --Dry-Erase board - This is a pretty crucial item to dorm life.  It's a great way for people to leave messages and let you know they stopped by.  It's fun and functional.
         --DVD Player - Luxury.
         --Family/Friends Photos
    --Fan - This is definitely worth leaving room for, because the dorms can get very warm in the Winter.
         --Mattress pad
     --Night-light - I don't think I've ever known anyone to have one of these.  The room's so small it would probably keep you up at night.
         --Pillow (2)
         --Posters - This is a great way to decorate.  There is a poster sale on campus at the beginning of every semester and there is a poster store downtown in the Commons.
     --Potted plants - This can be high maintenance and messy, so I would stay away from this one.
         --Sleeping bag - You never know when you might have a guest on your floor or when you might want to go visit someone else!
         --Stereo - Luxury.
         --Sticky-tack - This is a great way to hang stuff on your walls.  Make sure you get the white stuff, because the blue stuff does not come off the walls well.  You don't want to be billed for damages.
    --Storage drawers or shelves - There is a wide variety of plastic shelving and drawer units to help you organize your life!
   --Telephone - You only need one in each room, so talk to your roommate.  I highly recommend getting a cheap phone that has a built in answering machine.
         --Television - Luxury.  Every residence hall has a TV lounge, so you don't need to go out and buy one for your room.
         --VCR - Luxury.  I will say that there are some classes in which you tape yourself (especially if you're an education major) so this can be handy for watching your own tapes.
 The List - Clothing

Obviously, this is one of the most challenging aspects of packing for college.  It's still warm and summery in August, but will be quite the opposite by December.  A good idea is to bring a minimum of winter clothes and then at Fall Break in October, take home summer clothes and bring back your winter clothes.

         --Belts
    --Dress clothes - Don't forget some nice clothes, because you'll end up needing them for something (class presentation, etc.).
         --Gloves - Definitely for the winter months.
         --Hat/Headband/Earmuffs - Keeping your ears warm is a wise idea when it gets cold out.
    --Hooks - Adhesive Hooks are very important for customizing your room!  Make sure you use the 3M adhesives that can be removed without damaging the walls.
         --Jackets - A winter coat, if nothing else.
         --Jeans/Khakis/etc.
         --Jewelry & Watch - You don't want to be late for class!
     --Nylons - The only time you would need these would be if you need to dress up for a concert or interview.
         --Pajamas - Your roomie probably would prefer you didn't sleep naked. ;-)
      --Robe - It's generally pretty warm in the dorms, so this probably won't be worth the space it takes up.
         --Shirts
         --Shoes - Casual shoes, dress shoes, etc.
         --Shorts - You can send these home at Fall Break.
    --Sneakers - You'll need an extra pair of sneakers to get into the gym!
         --Socks - Don't forget dress socks too!
         --Sweaters
    --Sweatshirts/Hoodies - These are a staple.  They are comfy, warm, and fantastic.
         --Swim suit - We have an indoor pool, remember?
         --T-shirts
         --Underwear - Bring extra in case you fall behind with laundry!
         --Workout clothes
 The List - Desk Supplies

This list is very long.  A lot of these are little things you might want to remember, but some of them are just ridiculous.  We got this list from somewhere else, so don't laugh at some of these.

         --Address Book - Chances are you have this info stored on a computer, but this could be helpful nonetheless.
         --Backpack - You'll have a lot of books to carry!
    --Cables - Don't forget any hookups you need for your computer, game systems, or cable TV.  Ethernet cords are for sale in the Bookstore if you aren't sure what you need for Internet access.
         --Calculator - Helpful if you're taking a math course.
    --Computer - Don't feel compelled to spring for a laptop; I can personally tell you a desktop will serve you just as well.
         --Desk lamp - This can be nice, but I would advise against the metal ones, as they can get very hot.  Also, a light with a shade will provide a much more comfortable light.  Remember that halogen lights are not allowed.
         --Desk tray organizer
         --Diskettes, ZIP Disks, Blank CDs
         --Envelopes
         --Erasers
     --File Cabinet - They're hard to move and there isn't really room.  I don't know anybody who has one.
         --Folders
         --Glue/Gluestick
         --Highlighters
         --Keyboard
         --Labels
         --Markers
         --Mouse & Pad
         --Notebooks
         --Notepaper
         --Paper clips
      --Paper shredder - There is absolutely no reason you would need this.
         --Pencil cup
         --Phone cord
         --Postage stamps
         --Post-it Notes
         --Printer
         --Printer paper
         --Reference books
         --Rubber bands
         --Ruler
         --Scissors
         --Software
         --Speakers
         --Stapler Remover
         --Stapler & Staples
    --Surge Protector - Extension cords are NOT allowed, so surge protectors are the way to go.  Some surge protectors come with very long cords, so if your outlets are in inconvenient locations, there is an effective way to get your electricity to reach without breaking the rules!
         --Tape
    --Three-hole Punch - This is extremely handy to have for organizing your notebooks.  Many professors will require you to keep organized notebooks.
         --Trash bin - Don't get something too big.  Some plastic grocery bags make handy garbage bags!
         --White-out
 The List - Kitchen/Cooking

The items on this list are probably the least essential.  Though every residence hall is equipped with a full kitchen or kitchenette, you will probably be eating in the dining halls most of the time.  Remember, all of this stuff has to be stored somewhere in your room, so use your best judgment about what you really need.
         --Can opener
         --Favorite recipes
     --Frying pan (small)
         --Knife  
   --Mini-Fridge/Rented Microfridge - Every hall has a fridge, but having your own can be much more convenient.
          --Mug
    --Nalgene/Water bottle 
         --Oven mitt
     --Paper towels - Save the space, there are paper towels in the dorms already.
     --Pizza cutter - It might get used, but is it worth the space it takes up?
         --Plastic food containers
         --Plastic glasses
         --Plastic plates & bowls
         --Portable water filter
         --Pot for boiling water
         --Utensils
         --Ziploc bags
 The List - Food

This is a tricky category.  Try to balance your snacking wants and dietary needs.  I definitely recommend having some sort of breakfast if you don't eat breakfast in the dining hall!

     --Bottled water - This is very wasteful.  If water quality is a big issue, get a portable filter.  Get your own water bottle and reuse it.
         --Cereal
      --Condiments - You won't really need these in your room.
         --Packaged foods
         --Favorite snack
         --Fruit - You can take a piece of fruit from the dining hall, so take advantage of that!
         --Jam/Jelly
         --Juice boxes - Don't forget they're recyclable too!
         --Nuts
         --Oatmeal (instant)
         --Peanut butter
         --Popcorn
         --Power bars
         --Raisins
         --Ramen Noodles
         --Soda (or "Pop" as you crazy western New Yorkers call it)
         --Soup
         --Sports Drink
 The List - Laundry

Thanks to the Residence Hall Association's efforts last year, laundry is now included in tuition costs, so you don't have to worry about saving up quarters to use the washers and driers!  Still, you need all your own supplies, so here's a list to get you set up.

         --Clothes hangers
     --Clothes pins - I suppose you could rig a line in your room, but it doesn't seem worth it at all.
         --Detergent
     --Drying rack - Unless you have special fabrics that can't be put in the drier, this will just take up room in your room.
         --Fabric softener
         --Iron, Ironing Board - They make little ones that are easier to store.
         --Stain Remover
 The List - Cleaning

It's important to keep a clean room.  A clean room is a happy room.  It sounds trite, but I promise you it's true.

         --Dish detergent - Get a little bottle to clean mugs, water bottles, and the other little things you might need to wash.
         --Dish cloth
         --Dish towel
         --Dusting cloth
         --Lysol
    --Room freshener - I have found that one of the little plug-in air fresheners really makes a big difference.
         --Small vacuum - Every residence hall has a vacuum, but sometimes it's more convenient to just use your own.
 The List - Miscellaneous Items

Here are a whole bunch of things that didn't seem to fit under the other categories!

         --Batteries
     --Beach towel - This would only be necessary if you're going to be using the pool.
         --Board games - Cranium and Taboo are dorm-life favorites
      --Bug Spray - I can't imagine you would need this very often.
         --Camera (and Film if not digital)
         --Cards - You can't play Mafia or Texas Hold'em without cards!
         --Duct Tape - You'd be amazed at how handy it can be.  It's good for removing warts, too, in case you didn't know!
          --DVD's
      --Earplugs - Hopefully you and your roommate will be considerate enough to each other that these won't be necessary.
    --Flashlight - The campus is well lit.  Unless you bury things under your bed or are obsessed with flashlight tag, you won't need this.
         --Light bulbs - You only need these for your own lamps; the campus Physical Plant will replace bulbs in the room's light fixtures.  I highly recommend investing in Compact Fluorescent Light bulbs (CFLs), as they generate less heat, use less energy, and I personally think they produce a nicer light.
         --Safety pins
         --Sewing kit
         --Sports Equipment - Just remember it has to fit in your room somewhere!
         --Sunglasses
         --Umbrella
         --Videos
 The List - Essential Items

Here are a few things you definitely don't want to forget.

         --Bank account/checks - If you use the campus's check cashing, you can write yourself a check to withdraw money without paying ATM fees!
         --Driver's license
         --Financial aid forms - If you have any that still need processed.
         --Medical Insurance Card
         --Registration information/Class schedule - You can access this online at any time.
     --Renter's Insurance - You won't really need this for anything.
         --Social Security Card
    --Student ID - You need this do pretty much anything on campus, including eating in the dining halls and buying books!
         --Passport
 Acronym/Quote of the Day and Valediction

 Acronym of the Day:

TIOLI - Take It or Leave It - The first week of classes, ICES (IC Environmental Society) hosts Take It or Leave It, a yard sale on the quad of items that students have left behind.  This is a great place to find some of those extra items you forgot at great prices!  Read a news article and watch a video about TIOLI!

Quote of the Day:

More powerful than the will to win is the courage to begin.

       --Author Unknown

That brings us to the end of another issue of E-vents, but there is more to come!  Next week is Part 2 of ways to get involved, plus some extra tips for preparing for move-in day!  Remember, you can hit me up if you have any questions about anything!   

Be well, do good things, and keep in touch.  Pizzout.

--Zack Ford, Your E-vents Guy

 An Important Request from the Religious Communities

The campus chaplains need your help!!  Do you have a "religious preference" or a strong cultural identity?  The chaplains are assembling databases for the Jewish, Protestant, and Catholic Communities that are housed in Muller Chapel and need your assistance to do so.

Take a moment to contact them with the following information: your name, hometown, email, phone number, and any information you want to share.  By collecting this information, it will help them stay in contact with you throughout the year!  Here is the contact information for the chaplains:

HILLEL (Jewish) - Michael Faber, faber@ithaca.edu
   www.ithaca.edu/hillel

Protestant - Meredith Ellis, mellis@ithaca.edu

Catholic - Mary Humenay, mhumena@ithaca.edu

 Zack's Interesting Tidbits - Thoughts of Summer

ZITs is a weekly feature of E-vents during the school year.  You never know what my tidbits will be from one week to the next.  One week I might be telling you all about the cool waterfalls around Ithaca, and the next week I might be expatiating about which fast food restaurants have the best BBQ Sauce, and the following week might even be just a completely random and (hopefully) humorous story from my witty imagination.

This week, just for kicks, I'm just going to share a few personal thoughts.  I'm sure it must be strange for you to be getting these emails from somebody you don't even know, and you're supposed to believe that I'm a real person and actually a fellow student.  I can tell you that it is equally as strange to be helping you with your transition as first-year students as I prepare for my senior year.  It really feels like just yesterday that I was in your shoes, and it's hard for me to believe that three years have already passed.  I'm about halfway through Life of Pi, and as I read about Pi Patel's journey, I keep thinking about my own journey.  I remember reading my own First Year Reading Initiative book, The Color of Water and having a very different perspective when I related the book to my own life.  It goes so fast, and you don't even realize how you grow.

I hope you guys (as in guys and gals) are as excited as I am for you.  Ithaca College is at a very exciting place in its life, and you are really going to get a great education.  The students of a school truly are the life of the institution, and if you live up your time spent here, both you and the college will benefit as a result.

That's why this week's E-vents (and some of the next issue) are dedicated to ways to get involved.  The organizations listed here are just a few of the larger groups you can join, but there are over 160, so take the time to explore them all.

The complete list of clubs and organizations can be found here:

http://www.ithaca.edu/csli/orgs/directory/

This week we feature five organizations.  The first three, SAB, BOC, and IC After Dark all focus on planning events and entertainment throughout the year.  The last two, RHA and SGA, do plan events, but focus more on representing your needs as an Ithaca College student.  Note: Some of the websites have not been updated for the new year yet, but they will be!

SAB - Student Activities Board

What They Do: SAB organizes the widest variety of events for students, almost all of which are free for students to attend.  The events they organize fall into five categories: Music, Comedy, Speakers, Special Events, and Films.  Here are a few events they've done in the past year or two: Anthony Rapp [Speakers], Mae [Music/Bureau of Concerts], Mike DeStefano [Speakers], Upright Citizens Brigade Improv Group [Comedy], Annual Stand-Up Comic Competition [Comedy], Adam Day [Music], Hypnotists [Special Events], Texas Hold'em Poker Nights [Special Events], Open Mic Night [Music], Involvement Fair [Special Events], Drive-In Movies [Films], and more!

Structure:  The leadership of SAB is an Executive Board comprised of the following: Executive Director, Assistant Executive Director, Webmaster, Director of Finance, and then the six committee chairs.  Then, of course, there are all the amazing volunteers that sit on the six committees and help plan the different events.   The six committees are Music, Comedy, Speakers, Special Events, Films, and Ad/PR.  Each committee holds its own meetings on various nights of the week.

What a Person in SAB Gets to Do:  By working for SAB, you will get to meet celebrities (even little ones), learn how to deal with contracts and artists, learn how to successfully execute an event (from beginning programming to clean-up), and get to work with an outstanding group of individuals who dedicate their time and effort into bringing great events to campus!

How to Get Involved:  You can sign up to join an SAB committee at any time!  There will also be a recruitment night on Tuesday, September 5th at 6:00 PM in the Clark Lounge.  (Don't worry, it'll be in E-vents!)  You'll be able to learn more about the group and which committee you might be interested in joining.

Who's in Charge: Laurel Dreher, Executive Director
 Contact Email: ldreher1@ithaca.edu

Website:  www.ithaca.edu/sab
Facebook Group (Login first): http://ithaca.facebook.com/group.php?gid=2201063379
BOC - Bureau of Concerts

What They Do: BOC is responsible for organizing several large concert events throughout the year.  Since these events don't occur on a regular basis, BOC isn't always as busy from week to week as some other organizations are, but when it comes time for an event, things get very busy!  Some of BOC's past shows include Mae, Less Than Jake, O.A.R., Something Corporate, Keller Williams, and The Roots.

Structure:  There are eight committees that coordinate the different aspects of the events, and they are organized by the Executive Chair.  These committees work throughout the year, but it's when shows happen that a lot of volunteers are needed.  In fact, over 100 volunteers are needed to make a concert a success, since sometimes over 3,000 people will attend!

What a Person in BOC Gets to Do:  Volunteers assist with all aspects of concert management, including artist services, security, ticket sales, set-up, clean-up, and more.  There are usually opportunities to meet the celebrity guests, plus you are getting to help organize some of the biggest and most exciting events on campus!

How to Get Involved:  BOC won't have a recruitment night until it comes time for their first concert, so stay tuned for more information about upcoming shows.  In the meantime, check out their website for more info!

Who's in Charge: Joe Lerner, Executive Director
Contact Email: boc@ithaca.edu

Website:  www.ithaca.edu/boc
Facebook Group (Login first): http://ithaca.facebook.com/group.php?gid=2201293943

IC After Dark

What They Do: After Dark plans unique late-night entertainment throughout the year.  All After Dark events are totally free to all students, and aside from being a ton of fun, the events almost always include lots of exciting prizes!  Past events include E Komo Mai, Urban Cowboy, the Superbowl Party, The Dating Game, and Casino Night, with prizes like Televisions, Sony PSPs, Digital Cameras, iPods, gift certificates to chain retailers, and more!  After Dark will bring back many of these events, plus continue to plan new and original events for the campus community!

Structure:  All the entertainment from After Dark is thanks to the Executive Board, which includes several different chairs who carry out the various tasks involved for each event.  Volunteers are recruited to help with the various events throughout the year.  Applications for the executive board positions take place in the Spring.

What a Person in After Dark Gets to Do:  Besides working behind the scenes to plan huge, fun events, After Dark members get to apply skills learned in the classroom, meet and network with college staff, and make new friends!  It's definitely a unique experience!!

How to Get Involved:  If you'd like to be a part of IC After Dark, check out their website!  You can also find them at the Involvement Fair in early September.  (Stay tuned for more details!!)

Who's in Charge: Nick Fusco, Executive Chair
Contact Email: afterdark@ithaca.edu

Website:  www.ithaca.edu/afterdark
Facebook Group (Login first): http://ithaca.facebook.com/group.php?gid=2201075118

RHA - Residence Hall Association

What They Do: RHA is designed to represent your interests as a student on campus.  Since almost every student lives in a residence hall at some point, pretty much every student is represented by RHA.  The RHA Assembly and Executive Board meet once a week to hear concerns from the community, then address those issues through advocacy.  For example, thanks to the efforts of RHA, laundry facilities are no longer coin-operated and are more energy efficient.  In addition, they organize programming and support other organizations to help foster a strong living community.  This past year, RHA helped bring Mark Hertzgaard (journalist and author of "Earth Odyssey") and Colby Buzzel (Iraq veteran, blogger and author of "My War") to campus.  Popular past programs include Ithaca Idol, Sexfest, Battle of the Cans, and the IC Flea Market.

Structure:  The Residence Hall Association is made up of an Executive Board and Assembly.  The Assembly is made up of representatives from each residence hall cluster.  Those representatives gather feedback from their fellow residents and also serve on various committees, such as programming, public relations, conferences, and sustainability.   Assembly meetings are every Monday night at 8:15 PM in the North Meeting Room. 

What a Person in RHA Gets to Do:  By joining RHA, students get the opportunity to make great friends, get excellent student leadership experience, establish themselves as a presence in the residence halls, and have a very large voice concerning major events and changes that happen on campus.  RHA members also facilitate and participate in awesome campus-wide programs and attend RHA conferences all over the United States.  Most importantly, you get to be an active and contributing member of the Ithaca College community.

How to Get Involved:  To get involved with RHA, just show up at Assembly meetings, Monday's at 8:15 PM in the North Meeting Room.  The first meeting is September 4th (Labor Day).

Who's in Charge: Andrew Bernier, President
Contact Email: rha@ithaca.edu

Website:  www.ithaca.edu/rha
Facebook Group (Login first): http://ithaca.facebook.com/group.php?gid=2201284099

SGA - Student Government Association

What They Do: SGA is unlike any other organization because it is actually part of the institutional structure of Ithaca College.  It is the sole official voice of the student body of Ithaca College, so you are always represented by Student Government while you are a student at IC.  One of SGA's main responsibilities is allocating funding to all the other student groups on campus.  As the representative body of the students, SGA also advocates on behalf of IC students on and off campus, including broad issues like Sustainability and Handicap Accessibility on campus, as well as specific issues, like this past year when SGA worked to establish Martin Luther King, Jr. Day as an observed holiday by the college.  Members of SGA also spend time building community relations and lobbying on behalf of students to the local, state, and national governments.  SGA cosponsors many programs throughout the year and helps coordinate events such the Homecoming Pep Rally and National Collegiate Alcohol Awareness Week.

Structure:  The Student Government Association is made up of an Executive Board and Senate.  The Executive Board include the Student Body President (that's me, incidentally!) and four Vice Presidents.  There's also the Student Trustee, a student selected to sit on the Board of Trustees.  The Senate has 24 Senators, including four from each class and one from each of the schools.  The Senate uses a committee structure to accomplish its different tasks, and is also responsible for making sure students serve on all the different committees across campus, like Parking Policy and Campus Life.  The Senate meets once weekly and all meetings are of course open to the public!

What a Person in SGA Gets to Do:  By serving as an SGA Senator, you get to build amazing leadership skills while serving your fellow students.  You will learn a lot about the institution and be able to answer tons of questions for your constituents.  Staff and administrators constantly visit SGA for input and to discuss what else is happening on campus.  Even if you aren't elected as a Senator, you can still contribute by sitting on various campus committees where you can ensure that a student voice is heard and actually create change at Ithaca College!

How to Get Involved:  SGA is holding a recruitment night on Thursday, August 31st at 7:00 PM in the Clark Lounge.  You can meet the existing members and get information about elections.  Elections will take place on September 13-14, so stay tuned for information about running for Senate!  SGA meetings are every Tuesday night at 8:15 PM in the North Meeting Room beginning September 5th, so if you want to just help out with a committee or stay informed about what's happening on campus, feel free to come to the meetings!!

Who's in Charge: Zachary Ford, President
Contact Email: sga@ithaca.edu

Website:  www.ithaca.edu/sga
Facebook Group (Login first): http://ithaca.facebook.com/group.php?gid=2204134682

Up Close and Personal with The E-vents Guy

Hey there!  Welcome to Vol. 2 of Flopper's Summer Digest, your guide to starting off an exciting four years at Ithaca College!  This week, we talk about that book you were handed at Orientation, whether or not you should bring a car, and studying abroad, but first, I thought you deserved to know a little bit more about Zack Ford, your E-vents guy.  That's me!  So I decided I would interview myself so you could learn about me.

E-vents:  Hi Zack!  Thanks for agreeing to talk with us today!
Zack Ford:  Oh, it's my pleasure, for sure!
E:  So you're a senior Music Education major, right?  What's your instrument?
ZF:  I'm a pianist actually, but I sing sometimes too (preferably when nobody's listening!).
E:  And what makes you qualified to write this exciting newsletter that goes out to so many students?
ZF:  Well, it's an interesting question.  I don't think there's something special about me except that I got lucky when I was invited to write E-vents two years ago.  I had a column in my high school newspaper and I've been an Orientation Leader for two summers here at IC, so I guess the combination of my journalistic personality, love of serving first-year students, and perfectionism work well with E-vents.
E:  What else do you do on campus?
ZF:  Well, I do a lot of work with the Student Government Association and some of the community service organizations, so I guess it's obvious I like serving others!  I'm also a member of a professional music fraternity, which also does community service, incidentally.
E:  Quite an active guy!  Which superhero would you say you identify with the most?
ZF:  Oh, it's definitely Spiderman.  Like Peter Parker, I'm a pretty typical, laid-back guy.  I'm not from another planet or a rich businessman, I'm just an average guy with an average life.  I just happen to work hard to help other people in addition to that normal life.
E:  How did you meet Flopper?
ZF:  Oh, that's a story for another time!  Maybe I'll share it down the road, in like... November or something.  Flopper's a great pal, and his story can't be abridged to a little interview.
E:  Well, this interview has taken up enough space, so we should probably end it so the readers don't get bored and annoyed with it.  Thanks for chatting with us, Zack Ford!
ZF:  No problem, have a good one.

Contact Zack anytime...

Crossing Boundaries - The Life of Pi

At Orientation, you should have received your very own copy of Yann Martel's Life of Pi.  This novel is this year's First Year Reading Initiative selection.

What is the FYRI?  It's an exciting program that brings students together and kicks off the week of classes!  Between now and when you come back in August, you need to read Life of Pi and get ready to discuss it.  You'll get to meet up with other students and discuss the novel in a group setting, facilitated by staff, faculty, administration, and upperclassmen from across campus.  It's a unique opportunity to meet new people and casually discuss an award-winning novel.

As you read, there are discussion questions for you to consider.  You can find them on the bookmark that was included with your copy of the book.  In the discussion groups, those questions will help guide conversation, but certainly will not limit it!  Your group will be able to share any insights you have from reading the book.  It's also neat to talk about how the themes in the story relate to the experience you will all have as you begin this new chapter in your lives.  (I'm reading the novel right now too and I'll be with one of the discussion groups, so I'm excited to talk with you about it!)

A week after the reading discussion is another event: a presentation by Dr. Azar Nafisi.  Author of Reading Lolita in Tehran, Dr. Nafisi will discuss the transformative power of literary imagination.  Her presentation will relate to many of the themes in Life of Pi and will add to your experience of Crossing Boundaries!

Dates to Remember:
    Tuesday, August 29 - 11:15 AM - 12:45 PM - All across campus - Group discussions about Life of Pi.
    Tuesday, September 5 - 7:00 PM - Emerson Suites - Presentation by Dr. Azar Nafisi.

For more information about the First Year Reading Initiative, including book reviews, reading guides, and more, visit the library's FYRI website at http://www.ithaca.edu/library/fyri/

Sustainability - What the heck is it?

Sustainability.  It has... something to do with the environment?  Or like, sustaining life on our planet?  Wait!  What does this even have to do with coming to college??

EVERYTHING!  Ithaca College is very dedicated to sustainability, and with good reason.  Sustainability isn't just about protecting the environment; it's about society and the economy too.  All three work together, so for example, if we find a new clean way to generate energy without burning fossil fuels, then people will invest in it and it will generate money.  If we find ways to save money, then we can dedicate more money to social issues.  It can get tricky to wrap your head around, but just remember that Sustainability is good for the environment, good for your wallet, and good for you!

Now, how will you experience it while you're here?  Well, for one, you'll see it in the construction of the new Business School, which will be completed while you're still at IC.  You should read more about its unique architecture here: http://www.ithaca.edu/business/architect/

Why should you care about Sustainability?  The Ithaca College budget is about almost entirely dependent upon the money we pay as students (room, board, and tuition).  The more money we help IC save, the more we're helping to keep tuition from going up more each year!  Here are some ways that you can incorporate sustainability into your everyday life at IC:

 Recycle!  Every residence hall room at IC is equipped with two recycling bins.  Blue is for paper, Green is for containers.  Those colors are standard across campus, so get used to them!  Recycling is so easy that there's no excuse not to do it!  Make it part of your regular behavior!

 Take less food!  In the dining hall, it's tempting to take a lot of food all at once.  Instead, take smaller portions and then go back for more later.  That way, you don't waste as much.  If we all eat less, then they can serve us less, which means they have to buy less!  (Sometimes, we all waste a little food, but you can still rest easy knowing that all food scraps from the dining halls are composted!)

 Use less energy!  If we all work hard as students to save energy in our rooms, we can help save our institution a LOT of money AND make a big difference for the environment.  Small things can have a huge impact, so consider ideas like taking shorter showers, using Compact Fluorescent Light Bulbs, and turning off you computer (or at least your monitor) when you aren't using it.

 Get involved!  There are a lot of ways to support Sustainability while you're at IC:

ICES (Ithaca College Environmental Society) - This group of students works throughout the year to provide programming and opportunities to raise awareness about the environment.  They maintain an Organic Garden, bring speakers to campus, and organize "Take it or Leave it" (TIOLI), where students can give away things they might throw out and take things other students no longer want.  Find out more at http://www.ithaca.edu/ices/

REMP (Resource and Environmental Management Program) - REMP is dedicated to implementing sustainable initiatives across campus, working with faculty and student groups to find ways to be more resourceful!  It's responsible for the Compost Facility as well as OSCAR (Office Supply Collection and Reuse) which saves unused office supplies that faculty and student groups can reuse at no cost!  Learn more at http://www.ithaca.edu/remp

Students for Sustainability - This group of students formed just a few years ago to work towards establishing IC as a "national leader of sustainability in higher education."  They do a lot of advocacy work to help the college find new ways to operate more sustainably.  Read more about who they are and what kind of projects they work on at http://www.ithaca.edu/biology/sfs/

As you can see, sustainability is just as much about your budget and your life as a student as it is about serving the environment!  Stay tuned for more ideas about how to make your life at IC more sustainable!

Is Having a Car Worth Over $200???

This is a question only you can answer for yourself!  There is a question I can answer for you:

"Do I need to have a car on campus?" No.  There are a lot of activities on campus, so a lot of times there won't be good reason to go off-campus.  If you do want to leave campus, there is the TCAT, an excellent bus system that serves students well.  You can purchase a monthly or semesterly pass for a reduced rate!  There is also a local taxi service, which is a bit more pricey, but will take you anywhere you want to go (and is still a lot cheaper overall than paying that much to have your car on campus).  Call a taxi at 607-277-7777.

If you do bring a car with you, know that as a first-year student, it will cost $206 to buy your parking permit for the year.  You will also only be allowed to park in the two lots designated for green permits, the M extension and Z lots, which aren't very convenient.  (See these lots on the campus map: http://www.ithaca.edu/map/parking.php)

To purchase your permit, stop by the Office of Public Safety with your Ithaca College Student ID and a copy of your Vehicle Registration and you'll be all set to go.  Learn more about your transportation needs at the following links:

Ithaca College Parking and Traffice Services - http://www.ithaca.edu/safety/pts_geninfo.htm

TCAT (Tompkins Consolidated Area Transit) - http://www.tcatbus.com

Ithaca Dispatch (Taxi Service) - http://www.ithacataxi.biz/

Think Ahead: Studying Abroad

It is NEVER too early to start thinking about if you'd like to spend a semester studying abroad.  In some of the more demanding degrees, you really should start planning now so that you can plan out your course load to accommodate the semester away.  There are a ton of options, but I thought I'd highlight just a few to give you something to think about.

Studying abroad programs can be kind of confusing, because some are "affiliated" with IC and others aren't, so you'll have to discuss your options with the Office of International Programs.  Ithaca College offers three programs of its own that are worth checking out:

Washington, D.C. - I know, it's not abroad, but it's a really cool program!  You'll spend a whole semester living and studying in our nation's capital, plus you'll have a really exciting internship!  It's not in another country, but is definitely a program worth considering.  Here's the website: http://www.ithaca.edu/washington/index.php

Ithaca College London Center - Spend a semester in London, England at IC's very own London Center.  This program is perfect for to take some classes in various liberal arts, music, and theatre, plus business, sports studies, and communications too!  Check out more at the London Center website: http://www.ithaca.edu/oip/London/index.htm

Walkabout Down Under - This fairly new program takes you to three different universities in Australia!  You'll learn much about the culture and history of Oz as you travel across the continent.  Learn more about it online at: http://www.ithaca.edu/oip/australia/index.htm

Like I said, these are just a few of the options!  There are so many more, plus a lot of short-term programs as well!  Take some time and explore the Office of International Programs website: http://www.ithaca.edu/oip/abroad.htm

Intro Part 1 - What The Heck is E-vents?

Welcome!  E-vents is coming at you!  During the school year, E-vents will arrive in your Inbox every Thursday, keeping you informed about all of the events that are happening on campus.  It's the most complete and reliable events calendar on campus!  Not only that, E-vents is packed with all kinds of other info about how to get involved on campus, sights to see around Ithaca, community events, study tips, and more!  Flopper's Summer Digest is full of tons of information to get you ready for your arrival on South Hill in August.  If that's not enough, you have the cutest penguin and the wittiest commentator to keep you entertained and keep you thinking!  Speaking of which...

Intro Part 2 - Who the Heck are Zack and Flopper?

Your host for E-vents is me, Zack Ford.  I try to keep things funny and exciting, but my sidekick Flopper the Dancing Penguin is there for those times when I start to get dry.  I'm an IC student, like you!  I am solely responsible for the content of E-vents each week, so if you have any suggestions, let me know.  I'm always open to new ideas.  E-vents only comes out once a week, but I'm available 24/7, so if you just want to chat or you have questions about anything related to Ithaca College, I'm your guy!  I'm sort of like the Orientation Leader who never goes away.  You'll learn more about me and Flopper as the weeks go on.

Contact Zack anytime...
 - By Email: icflopper@gmail.com
 - On AIM: ICInfoDudeZ

Note: If you cannot see Flopper in Webmail, please do the following: In Webmail, click on "Options" at the top (it's the fourth from the left).  Select "Display Preferences."  Scroll down and make sure that "Show HTML Version by Default" is set to "Yes."  Then click Submit at the bottom, and you should be set.

Housing - Know Your Options

So even though July 1st was the deadline to submit your housing preference form, it's still not too late to consider these other awesome options!  If any of these sound interesting to you, contact the Office of ResLife by this Friday, July 14, at (607) 274-3141 for more information.

First Year Program: This is an AWESOME place to live!  These three residence halls are staffed by very cool RAs and are a great place to make friends for life.  The RAs plan a lot of fun activities and provide tons of resources to make your first year at IC the best!  The First Year Program is housed in BRT - Boothroyd, Rowland, and Talcott Halls.  Find out more here!

H.O.M.E. - Housing Offering a Multicultural Experience:  HOME is a special residence hall designated for international students and any students committed to expanding their multicultural experiences.  Residents of HOME are required to take a multiculturally-themed class during their first semester and participate in events and programs throughout the year.  Terrace 2 is where you'll find the HOME program.  Learn more here!

Vecinos - Vecinos is a special community for any individual interested in actively using the Spanish language.  Regular programs will be devoted to learning the language as well as studying the culture and history of Spanish-speaking countries.  All levels of Spanish speakers are welcome!  Read more here!

Sustainably Conscious Living Community - The Sustainably Conscious Living Community is designed for students committed to improving their relationship with the environment, society, and economy.  This community becomes extremely close-knit through community meetings, group dinners, and educational opportunities throughout the year.  Here's some more info!

There are also options for housing with extended quiet hours and substance-free lifestyles.  Check them out!  They're all great places to live!

Meal Plans - What's the Deal?

A lot of folks have questions about which meal plan is the best, and it's hard to say.  You have to find what works best for you!  (Luckily, you have a little time after classes start to change your meal plan!)

Your choices are the 20, 14, and 10 meal plans.  A little math will reveal that the 20 meal plan is the best deal, but that's assuming you use all 20 meals every week and don't mind going to the dining halls.  If you're like me and love breakfast, then this plan's perfect for you.  Some people prefer to skip breakfast or just grab a bagel and coffee, so in that case, you might prefer the 14.  All residence halls do have kitchens, and I've known many folks who've just made their own meals, so maybe you'd rather stick with the 10.  Only you can be sure which plan works best for you.

Bonus Bucks are pretty cool if you use them well.  You can spend them on snacks at Mac's General Store, sandwiches at BJ's sub shop, coffee, smoothies, and at the food court.  They last all year, but make sure you use them or you'll lose them!

Meal plans also now come with 3 guest passes!  This is a new feature that we've been dying to have.  That means when your friend from another school or your parents visit, you can get them into the dining hall at no extra cost.  This is extremely convenient, but don't forget that you have them!

If you want to change your Meal Plan option, just stop by the Bursar's office in Job Hall and they'll take care of you!  You have to do it in the first couple weeks!

Jump the Gun - Get Involved Before Classes Even Begin!

There are three awesome opportunities specifically for you, first-year students, that you can sign up for RIGHT NOW!  All of these programs allow for you to come to Ithaca a few days early and move in to your real residence hall room for the school year.  Then you'll spend a couple days making new friends and having really cool experiences!  Check out these three programs and then click below to apply!

Community Plunge: Take the plunge into service in the Ithaca community!  You'll be teamed up with other first-year students as well as two upper-classmen leaders who will guide you and work with you through the program.  (I'm one of the leaders!)  Together, your group will be dispatched to various organizations throughout Ithaca to spend a few days doing community service.  It can be work, but it's a ton of fun and extremely rewarding!  This is a great way to learn more about service opportunities at IC!

ECHO - Experiencing Connections by Heading Outdoors:  ECHO is an overnight camping trip for first-year students.  You'll make tons of new friends plus connect with older students, faculty, and staff as you explore the Finger Lakes National Forest.  Central NY has some beautiful landscapes, so if you love the outdoors, ECHO is for you!

Lead-in:  Want to get a head-start on the path to becoming a leader at IC?  This new program is a great way to interact with others interested in leadership, so you'll make great new friends and identify leadership skills within you that you might never have realized before.  You'll get to work with current IC student leaders, and you'll have a transition mentor to support you as you explore all the new opportunities around you!

If you're interested in any of these three programs, you can apply online RIGHT NOW!  The online application can be found at: http://www.ithaca.edu/csli/forms/cp_echo_leadin1.htm

The Sun, the hearth of affection and life, pours burning love on the delighted earth.

Be well, do good things, and keep in touch.

--Zack Ford, Your E-vents Guy

Well, it's here.  Your last issue of E-vents.  At least officially.  Well, maybe I'll send out one more next week.  Yeah, I will, just for kicks.

If you do nothing, you will continue to get E-vents throughout next year.  I might repeat some features, because E-vents is still designed to help first-year students and there will be a whole new group of first-year students to write for!  But, by staying subscribed, you can continue to get the ZackFord dry and witty humor you've come to love.  Oh, and you can stay informed about what's happening on campus too!  That'll still be part of E-vents!  So now it's decision time:

To unsubscribe from E-vents: 1)  Go to http://lists.ithaca.edu.  2)  Type in your email address.  3)  Click "Go."  4)  Uncheck the box next to "e-vents".  5)  Click "Apply."  You're done!  We'll miss you!

Your Job For This Week:  Tell me what your favorite E-vents moment was.  Next week's issue will just be a countdown of everybody's favorite E-vents moments.  You don't have to remember which issue it came from; I'll be able to find it!  Email me at icflopper@gmail.com to vote for your favorite E-vents moment!  (Just say like, "That time when you did such-and-such" or "when you talked about such-and-such".)

Flopper Talks A Lot:

Have you been paying attention?  Every week, Flopper makes a pop culture reference that somehow makes a reference to E-vents.  I make these up on my own, and they usually reflect what a dork I can be.  Here, for your entertainment, is a year in review of Flopper Says.  See if you can tell where they all come from!!  (Do the two Dane Cook references make up for the two Pocahontas references?  I know, I know, you don't have to answer that question.)

Flopper says:  "Kick off your shoes in a fit of joy!  It's E-vents!"

Flopper says:  "It's raining, it's pouring, and even the old man is reading E-vents!"

Flopper says:  "It's Zack's birthday, and he'll write E-vents if he wants to."

Flopper says:  "Easy guys.  Zack puts his pants on just like the rest of you--one leg at a time--except once his pants are on, he writes E-vents."

Flopper says:  "Can you sing with all the voices of the mountain?  Can you paint with all the colors of the E-vents?"

Flopper says:  "E-vents is a many-splendored thing.  E-vents lifts us up where we belong.  All you need is E-vents!"

Flopper says:  "I don't like when E-vents wears tights."

Flopper says:  "You're all I ever wanted, you're all I ever needed (yeah), so tell me what to do now, because ah... ah... ah... ah... ah... I want E-vents!"

Flopper says:  "Shake it once, that's fine.  Shake it twice, that's okay.  Shake it three times, you're reading E-vents."

Flopper says:  "Discovered by the Germans in 1904, they named it San Diego, which of course in German means E-vents."

Flopper says:  "A spoonful of sugar helps the E-vents go down in the most delightful way."

Flopper says:  "It's automatic.  It's systematic.  It's hydromatic.  Why it's E-vents!"

Flopper says:  "Viva la vie E-vents!"

Flopper says:  "Ain't no mountain high enough, Ain't no valley low enough, Ain't no river wide enough... to keep me from getting E-vents."

Flopper says:  "Deck the halls with boughs of E-vents, Fa la la la la, la la la la."

Flopper says:  "E-vents is mightier than the sword."

Flopper says:  "E-vents: The other white meat.  (Also available in vegetarian options.)

Flopper says:  "My E-vents brings all the boys to the yard, and they're like, it's better than yours."

Flopper says:  "You know what they call E-vents in Paris?  Le E-vents."

Flopper says:  "Come on, E-vents, let your body move to the music.  Hey Hey Hey, Come on, E-vents, let your body go with the flow.  You know you can do it!"

Flopper says:  "Somebody... somebody... can anybody find me E-vents to love?"

Flopper says:  "Orange you glad I didn't say E-vents?"

Flopper says:  "They paved E-vents and put up a parking lot."

Flopper says: "Because you know I'd walk a thousand miles if I could just see E-vents tonight."

Flopper says:  "E-vents gets knocked down, but it gets up again... you're never going to keep it down."

Flopper says:  "She says baby, it's 3 AM and I must read E-vents..."

Flopper says:  "I need some E-vents like I've never needed E-vents before... I had a little E-vents, now I'm back for more... Set your E-vents free, it's the only way to be..."

Flopper says:  "E-vents... she's spinning me around in E-vents again... oh, that skinny blond girl... something about the ages... I failed college algebra again, that skinny blond girl... and the E-vents and the ages and ages..."

Flopper says:  "That's the way, E-vents E-vents, I like it, E-vents E-vents!"

Flopper says:  "What I love most about E-vents is: you can't step in the same E-vents twice.  E-vents is always changing, always flowing.  But people I guess can't live like that, we all must pay a price.  To be safe, we lost our chance of ever knowing... what's around the E-vents!  Just around the E-vents!"

Flopper says:  "It's something unpredictable but in the end it's right, I hope you have the E-vents of your life."

Features Gone Missing

Did you notice that there were some features that had been around, but didn't really come back?

I stopped picking a Pick of the Week quite a while ago.  It was so hard to pick just one event each week, though sometimes, there are special events (like this week's IC Kicks Back Picnic) that deserve special attention.  I figured, out of fairness to all the other amazing events, I'd keep my nose out of the editorial process from week to week.  Of course, Zack's Pick of the Week Rewind, a review of what you missed at least week's Pick, dissolved as well.

Zack's Favorites was fun!  It'll probably be back next year.  Sometimes it was tricky coming up with topics when nobody emailed me questions, but it's fun to share cool things I've found with everybody.

ZackFord_Email.exe was very similar.  I realized that in a strict email format, my sarcasm isn't as funny as Strong Bad's.  I just came off as obnoxious, which is the last thing I want to do.  Plus, nobody sent emails to this feature, and it wasn't worth continuing.

Flopper's Digest.  Yeah, this was your space... and nobody really ever contributed to it.  It's still around I guess, but if nobody submits anything, then there's nothing to publish here.

Whose Digits Are In Zack's Cell Phone This Week?  This feature would be cool if anybody ever set me up to interview people.  Maybe next year, I'll just interview random people who are actually in my phone.  That might be fun.

Zack Picks on Neighbor Ron... that was a good time.  I started to feel guilty, because Ron wasn't picking on me anymore.  Does that mean I won?  That's no fun.  But this feature evolved into Tales From Bob's House, which was just as exciting and entertaining!

A feature that never quite made it... the E-vents Vocabulary Challenge!  Throughout the Fall semester, my buddy Cody would feed me a vocab word most weeks to somehow work into E-vents.  This would turn into a game where you would go back and find all these neat words and then maybe win a prize or something.  But Cody never got around to finding all the words and figuring out the challenge, so I guess if you get bored, you can just go back and try to find the special words.  If you look, you can find words like "pernicious" and "betwixt."  It's a good time.

What's to come?  Stay tuned to E-vents next year to see!  (I have a whole summer to come up with new ideas!!)

Tales From Bob's House

Series Finale - Who is Bob?, Conclusion

Previously, on Tales From Bob's House...

Baba Ganoush...Don't you wish your boyfriends were hot like us?...Who's House?  Bob's House...I just wish he had more to offer in response...Bob's a fine sailor...He's one of my role models...he's vegetarian and doesn't make me feel horrible for eating meat...I like chicken tenders...Cassie Johnson + Ryan Pangburn = <3...There are many situations for which the robe comes off the hook...man knitting...the Hammer has crossed boundaries few men have...Old Spice...Hairy Spice..."The Great Wall" is a Giant #3...a Crunchwrap Supreme and a Grande Soft Taco...A Poem by Dan, Ryan, Judd, Andy, and Zack...Bob is patient...Bob is a great listener...Bob is a party animal...Bob is dead???!!!

DUN DUN DUNNNNNN!!!

..........................


.........................



And now for the conclusion...

*Fade in*  Bob is dead????!!!

DUN DUN DUNNNNNN!!!

Yes.  It's true.  It's been some time since Bob was alive, but he's still our trusted companion.  He has lived all year with Judd, Ron, and Andy.  None of us are responsible for his death; we merely do our best to cherish his company as best we still can.  In the picture below, you can see Judd and Ryan posing with Bob, (as well as "April" from Ron's Calendar, who had to be censored).



So ends the tale from Bob's House.

ZITs:

Welcome to the penultimate issue of E-vents 2005-06!  Can you believe the year is almost over??

This is an important time of the year.  As we scramble to finish up all our projects, papers, and presentations and get ready for exams, it's important to wrap up the year and look forward to the next.

First, let me congratulate you on being part of the highest SGA voter turnout in Ithaca College history!  Last week, even despite the initial confusion and glitch in the system, over 2000 students logged on to cast their vote (a 22% increase from last year's turnout).  I commend you for your participation and engagement in the affairs of the campus!  If you have not yet heard the results, you may view them on the SGA webpage at http://www.ithaca.edu/sga/elections/index.php or in today's Ithaca (http://www.ithaca.edu/ithacan). 

One of the big decisions you need to make next week is if you would like to remain subscribed to E-vents for next year.  In the past, the entire list of subscriptions was always erased at the end of each year so that only the new first-year students were subscribed.  Recently, so many upperclassmen have requested to be back on E-vents that we decided we would give you the option this year to stay on.  Next week's issue will have more detailed instructions about what to do.

E-vents will be mostly the same next year.  Some features may come and go, but I will still be at the helm with Flopper at my side.  What will be neat is that as Student Body President, I'll have the opportunity to occasionally keep you more informed about some of the things happening on campus that might not be included normally in E-vents.  Other than those occasional Presidential featurettes, E-vents will be the same cheesy and informative weekly newsletter that you know so well.

By that note, be aware that there are many exciting opportunities to get involved in making Ithaca College a better campus next year.  For example, if you missed your chance to participate in the elections and get involved with Student Government Association, maybe you'd be interested in serving as SGA's Senate Chair or Governance Secretary, two very important positions that help the Student Government run more smoothly.  The Residence Hall Association is also a great way to get involved and help make a difference on campus, improving residence hall life for all current students and students to come!  Maybe you didn't get too involved on campus this year and are ready to dive in.  Check out the Student Organization Directory to see if there are some groups that maybe you'll want to seek out when you come back in the Fall.

There are also two very special ways you can be an important part of Ithaca College's history next year!

The first is the Capital Campaign.  Say what?  This Fall, Ithaca College will open its doors wide to the world in a big celebration of Bomber Pride.  This Capital Campaign is designed to bring a large sum of money that will help fund campus improvements such as an Athletics & Events Center, new academic programs, and probably most importantly: financial aid for students!  This campaign will be extremely exciting, and if we all work together, we can help the college raise money that will not only drastically improve the IC experience but will also make IC more affordable to students across the world who want to have their own IC experience!  Stay tuned for more details about the Capital Campaign in the Fall!

The second is Middle States Reaccreditation.  This is the process that happens every 10 years where the school is investigated to make sure that our programs are worthy of being accredited across the country, so it's very important!  I have enclosed a letter requesting your help in this process:
Dear Ithaca College Students:

During the next two academic years, Ithaca College will conduct a self-study that we hope will culminate in our reaccreditation by the Middle States Commission on Higher Education, our region's accrediting organization.  Additionally, the self-study will give us a chance to examine ourselves critically, to assess where we've been as an institution and where we're trying to go.

As co-chairs of the Self-Study Steering Committee, we would like to ask you to consider participating in our process for the next two years.  We are looking specifically for students to serve in one of the following ways:

1. As members of the self-study's task forces.  We anticipate impaneling groups of faculty, staff, administrators, and students to focus on the following topics:  leadership, planning, admission and retention, assessment procedures, faculty and staff, and student learning.  Ideally we'll have at least one student on each task force.

2. As members of the Steering Committee.  We hope to impanel four (or more) students to join the Steering Committee as it coordinates, reviews, and compiles the work generated by task forces throughout next year.  The Steering Committee (including faculty, staff, and administrators)  has already created an initial draft of our research design, and we anticipate submitting a final draft to the Middle States Association by June 1.  It is most important now for us to welcome students on to the committee as we enter the research and review phase of the next two years.

The task forces and the Steering Committee will meet regularly throughout the 2006-07 academic year, as we collect, compile, and analyze institutional data.  Groups will continue to meet during Fall 2007, as we finalize our report to Middle States.  Finally, we'll look forward to a site visit in early Spring 2008 by a team from other institutions that will evaluate us for reaccreditation.

We hope that you will be interested to join others at the College in this remarkable and important opportunity.  Please contact either of us for further information or to indicate your interest in serving on either the task forces or the Steering Committee.

With our best wishes for the remaining days of this semester,

Marian MacCurdy, Professor
Department of Writing
maccurdy@ithaca.edu
274-3659

Bill Pelto, Associate Dean
School of Music
pelto@ithaca.edu
274-3348

Look forward to a very exciting year in 2006-07.  For now, I wish you all the best in your final week of classes!  Remember to breathe and relax when you can!!

Do you know the name Rod Serling?  He's responsible for Patterns, Requiem for a Heavyweight, The Comedian, and famed television series The Twilight Zone.  He taught in the IC Communications School for 8 years, and this weekend we study his work!  Submitted for your approval are the events of the 2006 Rod Serling Conference.

The Protestant Community is sponsoring a 30 hour famine to raise money for World Vision, a Christian relief and development organization dedicated to helping children and their communities worldwide reach their full potential by tackling the causes of poverty.  For more info, contact ewetmor1@ithaca.edu. 

1:40 PM - Rod Serling Conference - Serling's Planet of the Apes - Park Auditorium - An examination of the evolution of Serling's screenplay for the 1967 film "Planet of the Apes" by Gordon Webb, assistant professor of television-radio at Ithaca College.  Based on material from the Rod Serling Archives and interviews with people involved in the film, Webb's research settled once and for all the issue of who first conjured up the movie's classic twist ending.

Tales From Bob's House

Series Finale - Who Is Bob?, Part I

Bob Is
A poem by Dan, Ryan, Judd, Andy, and Zack

Bob is hanging around in his room.
Bob is a cheeky fellow.
Bob is a Michigan sports fan.
Bob is stylish.
Bob is a fan of Hawaiian dress.
Bob is good at growing facial hair.
Bob is a great listener.
Bob is the kind of guy you can always depend on.
Bob is never angry.
Bob is gorges.
Bob is fluent in the language of love.
Bob is love.
Bob is wise.
Bob is patient.
Bob is pointy.
Bob is hopeful.
Bob is funny.
Bob is quiet.
Bob is a party animal.
Bob is stiff.
Bob is unwavering.
Bob is gross.
Bob is... dead?

My Beef with BK

Burger King has always been one of my favorite fast food restaurants.  I actually like McDonald's okay (because it's the only fast food restaurant within a half hour's drive of my house), and there are certainly days for Arby's and Wendy's, but when I get to choose, Burger King is usually a top choice.  I always feel so chill when I'm hanging out at the BK Lounge, enjoying my chicken tenders and refillable Dr. Pepper or Mr. Pibb when I'm lucky.

Despite the lack of a convenient BK growing up, it was still close to my heart, even as a child.  First of all, Burger King always had the coolest playgrounds as well as pretty quality toys.  And maybe you disagree, but I like to think of myself as slightly modest, or at least not egotistical, but how can you not feel special wearing a crown?  I still remember the great "new french fry" campaign with Mr. Potato Head; that was exciting!  And hands down, BK chicken tenders are one of my favorite foods ever.

My roomie Ryan and I will occasionally take a trip down to the fast food strip on 13 and partake in a Friday night meal that we know is not good for us.  It tastes good and we don't care, so it works out.  We share equal appreciation for the BK Lounge, so it's our usual stop.  The new marketing campaign, which includes witty commentary on all the boxes and cups is especially delightful.  A few weeks ago though, we made one such trip, and it was the most traumatic BK experience one could ever imagine.

I ordered my normal Chicken Tenders meal, large sized.  (I'm not a hog, but come on, I'm 6'3"!  A guy's got to eat!)  When I was handed my tray, I asked if I could have a second packet of BBQ Sauce.  The server replied that it would cost me like another quarter in order to get more BBQ Sauce.  I was astonished.  I was not going to sink so low as to pay for an extra little thing of BBQ Sauce.  I bitterly took my tray and took it over to the booth in which we'd be sitting.  I quickly noticed that my meal had not been Large sized (though I hadn't paid for it either).  This was a simple miscommunication that I could tolerate, but my temper was already escalating over the BBQ Sauce.  I filled my medium Dr. Pepper, had a seat, and began to open my new, unique-looking box of chicken.  Upon opening it, I realized that I had not ordered Chicken Tenders; in fact, "Chicken Tenders" were no longer on the menu.  These were "Chicken Fries."  Chicken Fries are very similar to chicken tenders, except they're a bit longer and with much less girth.  They were okay--pretty similar to the Tenders, but just not the same.  I was responsible with my sauce, finished my insufficient amount of fries, gulped down the rest of my Dr. Pepper, and we vacated the joint.

I'm not going to lie, I'm not sure this Burger King experience was real.  It could have just been a nightmare.  Last week, I took a solo trip back to BK.  A pretty and cheerful blond girl was working the register.  The gents in front of me in line paid by credit card but she couldn't find a pen, so I of course offered the one I always carry around in my pocket (because I'm dorky like that).  I noticed that the Chicken Fries were real and I was stuck with them, but they weren't too bad, so I ordered them again.  This time I made sure to clearly specify "Large" and she was so bubbly (and grateful for my pen loan) that I was feeling a lot better about this BK experience.  This time, I was actually going to have it my way!  Things were slow, so the same smiley employee prepared my tray, and guess what she included?  Two packs of BBQ Sauce.  It was amazing.

I've decided that Burger King has redeemed itself.  If you visit the BK website, you'll find that both the original Chicken Tenders and new Chicken Fries are still listed on the menu, so my old favorites might still be out in the world.  There is also hope that I can get sufficient dipping sauce with my meal, though I have no proof that the girl wasn't just doing me a favor because of the pen.  All of that aside, here's the best part.  Do you remember that Burger King commercial during the SuperBowl with the dancing condiments?  Except for Kermit's green energy, it was one of my favorite commercials that night, and now you can enjoy the Whopperettes anytime.  In fact, you can have them your way.  If you get bored this week, then check out www.whopperettes.com because it's pretty much the best thing ever.  I don't think I'll ever doubt that BK really is the Burger King.

Tales From Bob's House

Episode #Who Cares - Fast Food Favorites

Looking for a quick bite to eat but can't decide which chain to hit up or what to order?  Try these suggestions from the Bob's House crew!

Ron - A classic meal for a classic man!  Ron's choice is the Big Bacon Classic with a Large Fries from Wendy's.

Andy - Andy doesn't mess around with the burger joints; he heads straight for Arby's.  The "Great Wall" is a Giant #3, a roast beef sandwich with curly fries and a giant sized diet coke to wash it all down.

Dan - Dan's a picky guy and he knows what he likes.  If you really want to go all out, follow Dan's advice and pick up a burger from McDonald's, some fries from Burger King, and then a Wendy's frosty to top it off!

Judd - Remember that Judd is actually quite taller than me, so he needs a lot of food to keep him active and energized.  Stop by Wendy's and order the "Dutchman" and this is what you'll get: 3 junior bacon cheeseburgers, 5 chicken tenders with honey to dip, a bowl of chili with saltine crackers, a small frosty, a side salad, medium fries, and a cup of tap water.  That much food?  "Yes!" says Judd, "It's all off the 99 cent value menu, so it costs less than $9.00 for all that food and it'll entertain you for a solid hour!"

Ryan - (Prepare for inside joke!)  "For anyone who has been to the 518, the only option in the summer is Jumpin' Jacks... the best burger joint in the world.  If you find yourself there, make sure you order two cheeseburgers, a cheese dog ("dairy dog"), onion rings ("Indian"), and curly fries ("Twisters").  If you are feeling brave, have the onion and coleslaw topped Jackburger, which is the house specialty.  Don't forget to get an ice cream and leave a tip to hear those wonderful sounds of "SUBWAY!!!.......THANK YOU!!!"  Unfortunately, unless you are hardcore and willing to drive three hours for dinner, you may need to get something a little more local.  Being the oldest, and thus most mature member of Bob's House, I'm economical as I travel to Taco Bell, where I always live by the motto of 'Go Big or Go Home.'  Order a #7 (chicken quesadilla and taco), a Crunchwrap Supreme (Good to Go), and a Grande Soft Taco."

Bob - That's why I come up here.  Look at you, you're hungry.  You don't even blink, do you?  Quick, staring contest, me and you, NOW!  .......  You win, you always do.  That's why I come up here... NATURE!

Valediction:

So I was looking for quotes about food, and I found three that I just had to include.  So here are three inspirational quotes for the week!

The food here is so tasteless you could eat a meal of it and belch and it wouldn't remind you of anything.
                               --Redd Foxx

Cheese is milk's leap toward immortality.
                               --Cliff Fadiman

Abstain from beans.
                               --Plutarch

Have a great week everybody!

--ZackFord, The E-vents Guy
