April 11, 2006 - Welcome to a special "emergency" issue of E-vents! 

A quick announcement: President Peggy Williams will be speaking at tonight's Student Government Association meeting at 8:15 in the North Meeting Room (3rd Floor Campus Center).  She'll be talking about what we've accomplished this year and what to expect for next year.  It'll be an amazing opportunity to catch up on campus news and become informed voters.  If you have some time, I highly encourage you all to attend!

Flopper's Guide to the Elections:
What went wrong and what to do now

Yesterday, you all received an email about student government elections and were directed to www.collegevote.com/ithaca to vote.  Then, yesterday evening, you received another email about proxy ballots and glitches, and then last night the voting site was shut down.  So what the heck happened?

The short version: The elections had to be restarted.  All votes cast on Monday have been discarded.  Ignore the message about proxy ballots.  Log on today after 5:00 PM to cast your vote.  If you voted yesterday, you must revote to ensure your vote is counted.  http://www.collegevote.com/ithaca

The long version: So what the heck happened?  Here's a blow by blow report of what happened yesterday, as best I understand it:

At 9 AM, voting was activated and all students received an email about logging on to vote.

 Throughout the day, many students logged on to vote, but found that they couldn't vote for the proper candidates.  (For example, even though I am clearly a junior, I had "too many credits" to be allowed to vote for senior class officers or senior senators.)  At least 1300 students were affected by this glitch.

 Collegevote.com was notified of the glitch, and they prepared an email to send out to those 1300 students, informing them about how to get a proxy paper ballot so they could still cast their vote for the proper candidates and work around the glitch.

 This email was accidentally sent to everybody, resulting in massive confusion and a lot of concerned people worried about whether their vote counted or not.

 The Elections Committee contacted Collegevote.com last night and the voting site was shut down.  Collegevote.com has spent the day today (hopefully) correcting all of the errors so that everybody can vote for the proper candidates.  You will receive another email from Collegevote.com this evening explaining what happened.

 Even though several hundred students voted yesterday, all of those votes have been discarded.  Anybody who already voted yesterday will need to log back on starting this evening at 5 PM to cast their vote.  Elections will now run through Thursday evening at 9:00 PM.

 The bottom line: Please log on to www.collegevote.com/ithaca starting this evening and cast your vote.

Student Government elections are extremely important, because it's the one opportunity you have all year to ensure that the voice of every Ithaca College student is heard.  Remember, there also many empty slots available, so if you have any interest in running for Senator, it's not too late to run a write-in campaign!  If you have any questions about elections, you can contact me or Raphael Golberstein of the elections committee (rgolber1@ithaca.edu).

I hope this cleared everything up for everybody!  Have a great week and we'll see you Thursday!

--Zack Ford

ZITs:

Wow.  Can you believe there are only a couple weeks left?  It probably seems crazy that you guys and gals are already at the end of your first year, but let me tell you, when you get to the end of your third year?  It's totally unbelievable.

Congratulations to everybody who participated in this past weekend's 2nd Annual Relay for Life at Cornell!  Over 2100 students from IC and Cornell raised (as of Sunday at 7 AM) over $178,000!!!  More donations are still coming in over the next three weeks, so who knows how much the number might still climb!  (Last year's grand total was about $142,000.)  Thanks to everyone who worked hard for a great cause!  (Is anyone else still trying to catch up on sleep??)

So, I'm not going to lie, folks.  This week I am really uninspired as to what to write.  It's a freak occurrence, don't worry.  I was even looking back at last year for ideas and getting nothing.  You all already know what Intercom is (but it was new to students a year ago)... the earthworms aren't really coming out in full force yet, and I'm not sure how interested you all might be about all the worms coming out onto the sidewalk.  You'll see this yearly phenomenon for yourself soon enough.

This is what I thought I'd do: I'll give you more information about the Elections and encourage you to vote and then leave ZITs alone for the week and come up with something super exciting and special for next week!

Elections for Student Government are this week, Monday - Wednesday.  You'll all receive an email with the link to the voting site.  When you get there, you'll have to enter some information like your ID number and then you'll get to vote.  When you vote, you'll see pictures and platforms for each candidate.  It's super easy to select your choice and then you're done!  It takes all of three minutes, so I hope every one of you takes the time to vote this week!

To give you a head start, I thought I'd present you with each of the SGA Executive Board party's platforms, so you can read them and get an idea of what they stand for!  Each party could write up to 250 words, and this is exactly what you'll see when you go to vote next week.  (Don't forget to check out the coverage in today's Ithacan as well!)

The Bomber Party - Cornell Woodson, Stephen Dylag, David Miller, Aaron Bloom, and Jennifer Chicon
    The Student Government Association should be primarily about the concerns of Ithaca College students.  It will be a celebration of what students have and will contribute to the future of IC.  The Bomber Party will return SGA to the student body, encourage them to voice their opinions, and raise awareness that they are the central unit of Ithaca College.  We promise to be a more people-oriented E-Board.  Getting out into the community, talking with the students, and getting to know them will be a huge goal for us.  The Bomber Party cares about their constituents.

The F->WARD Party - Zachary Ford, Jill Cadby, Greg Mitstifer, Bevin Kennedy, and Michael Dunn
    The F->WARD Party is planning for both the short-term and long-term future of Ithaca College.  As we break ground on the new Business School and the first-ever Capital Campaign, sustainability must be one of our top priorities.  Saving the environment and saving money go hand in hand, so promoting sustainability ultimately helps keep tuition from increasing. In order to achieve our most desired goals, we must raise our voices, engaging in two-way communication with each other plus reaching out to administrators, the community, and the world at large.  It's important that YOU, as students, understand the fundamentals of Student Government so that SGA can effectively make the voice of Ithaca College students heard.  Student Government needs to be more approachable, personable, and convenient to work with, especially when it comes to getting funds for your organizations.  Strength is build through working together, and Student Government is what unites us as students.  This is the approach of The F->WARD.
    Our campus represents a diversity of cultures, values, and skills.  By combining the talents of our Five Schools and Division, plus the 150 student organizations on campus, we can develop our student body and campus into one of the most respected and admired institutions throughout the nation.  We must go beyond South Hill and build stronger relationships with our neighbors and other schools.  Let The F->WARD Party launch Ithaca College into a future where Bomber pride is envied by all others.

Zack's Favorites:

What is Zack's favorite place to hang out in Ithaca?

This is a tough question because there are so many cool places to go!

When it's 2:00 AM and you're hungry - I love hanging out at Mano's.  It's like a crucial part of the Ithaca experience.  A chocolate milkshake and grilled sweet roll in the middle of the night?  You might call it $4.50; I call it bliss.

When you're urgently hungry but don't have a lot of money - Wegmans!  It's actually quite a nice place to grab some dinner.  I usually load up my plate with sesame chicken and then head upstairs to eat it next to the talking trash can.  It's a pleasant little eating experience!

When you're hungry for a nice meal and a good atmosphere - The Lost Dog Cafe is such a cool place to chill.  The food is good (lots of vegetarian/vegan options too!), and the atmosphere is just so... Ithaca.  Who can say no to sweet potato fries?

When it's a warm and beautiful afternoon (weekday) - The Commons.  I've been in most of those shops multiple times, but I always find new and interesting things to look at.  It's just a pleasant place to chill, enjoy the sun, and interact with the community.

When it's a warm and beautiful afternoon (weekend) - I like to head out the road a bit to Taughannock Falls.  It's so beautiful, and it really just relaxes me to hike out the trail to the base of the falls and back again.  I still remember my first trip there with my INVOLVED group in September of my freshman year... the falls were one of the most beautiful things I'd ever seen and I was with a cool group of people and I just knew that I was at the right place.

On campus - Usually I'm hanging out wherever my friends or my responsibilities are, but sometimes when I need some relaxing alone time, I just enjoy strolling down by the chapel pond.  It's like a little haven of nature on campus and it's just so pretty and soothing.

No man is good enough to govern another man without that other's consent.

Have a great week everybody!  Pizzout!

--ZackFord, The E-vents Guy

Hey everybody!  Don't freak out, it's only Tuesday, I promise!  Here are just two important reminders about things happening this week!

SGA ELECTIONS KICKOFF!

Tonight - 6:00 - 8:00 PM - SGA Elections Kickoff in IC Square
    If you hadn't yet heard, elections are coming up for Student Government and tonight is your opportunity to meet all of the candidates!  Elections are held online, so it is very easy for every one of you to participate!  Here's a quick tutorial on the set up of our SGA:

    The SGA consists of an Executive Board and a Senate.

    The Executive Board (E-Board) has five members: the Student Body President, and the four Vice Presidents of Campus Affairs, Academics, Communications, and Business & Finance.  The members of the E-Board chair committees, meet with administrators, organize the SGA meetings, and maintain office hours, to name just a few of their responsibilities.  To get elected, parties of five run together for the Executive Board.  This year there are two parties:

    1.  The Bomber Party - Made up of:
       President - Cornell Woodson
       VP Academics - Stephen Dylag
       VP Business and Finance - David Miller
       VP Campus Affairs - Aaron Bloom
       VP Communications - Jennifer Chicon

    2.  The F->WARD Party - Made up of:
       President - Zachary Ford
       VP Academics - Jill Cadby
       VP Business and Finance - Greg Mitstifer
       VP Campus Affairs - Bevin Kennedy
       VP Communications - Michael Dunn

    The Senate is the voting body of Student Government.  Their general responsibilities include meeting weekly, sitting on committees, passing resolutions, and maintaining communication with their constituents.  There are 24 seats on the Senate that are filled as such:
       4 Senators from each Academic Class  (16)
       1 Senator from each School/Division (6)
       1 Transfer Student
       1 Graduate Student

Tonight you'll have the opportunity to meet all the candidates running from each constituency for the Senate seats.  The candidates for next year's Sophomore class seats are Phillip DeLaus and Julia Pergolini.

You'll get to meet all these candidates tonight in IC Square!  The parties and senatorial candidates will also be presenting to the SGA at their 8:15 Meeting upstairs in the North Meeting Room, so that's a great opportunity to attend an SGA meeting and find out more about all of the candidates!

Important:  There are still a lot of open slots for people to run!  Check things out tonight and consider running as a write-in!  (I've been elected twice on a write-in before!  It's worth it!)

RELAY FOR LIFE

Saturday, April 1 - 7:00 PM - 7:00 AM - Relay For Life in Cornell's Barton Hall

If you haven't yet signed up for Relay For Life, it's not too late!  We are on our way to raising an INCREDIBLE amount of money for the American Cancer Society, and everybody can still help!  Form a team now and start raising money for Saturday night!  Check out our IC Relay For Life webpage at:

http://www.acsevents.org/relay/ny/ithacacollege.

So far, Ithaca College has raised over $43,000, but we can still raise so much more!  Last year, Cornell and IC raised a combined $140,000 so we still have a lot more fundraising to do!  Join a team and help a great cause and enjoy a very fun event!!

I hope everyone's week is going well!  See you on Thursday!

My Amazing Spring Break

It's so long after the fact, but it's still worth sharing.  On Saturday, March 4, after enjoying some pizza with the students at the Washington, DC center, my new group of friends and I settled into our new home, the Community for Creative Non-Violence at Mitch Snyder Place in Central Washington.  The CCNV is a unique organization.  Unlike most homeless shelters who only provide a bed from 7 PM - 7AM (that's why homeless folks are always forced to carry their stuff around with them), the CCNV accommodates men, women, and children for up to six months.  This period of time allows people to get back up on their feet, find a job, and save up some money for a new home in a much more realistic way than those stuck on the street during the day.

Spending nine days living in the CCNV really opens your eyes to what other people are experiencing.  During our stay, among the services we were able to provide, we got to chat with some of the residents.  The stories they had to tell were amazing.  Many are veterans; some even have their doctorates.  You're really hit with the reality that anyone can become homeless at anytime.  But you also realize that they are people too, and it's very important to engage with them.  We would always say Hello as we passed by, and we even made a couple friends throughout the week with some of the residents.  It's a whole new perspective.

Throughout the week we volunteered at various sites.  The DC Central Kitchen is actually located in the same complex as the CCNV.  We helped them prepare an entire meal, and what was very cool was that there were some students from the University of North Carolina - Greensboro, so we made some new friends.  We got to eat what we cooked, and it was quite good.  There is so much good will reaching out to those in need, but not nearly enough.

Washington Parks and People was a very interesting experience.  The main goal of the organization is to clean up these park areas in poor parts of town to help lower crime and create a better community environment.  Our main task for the day was trash pick-up.  You know you're in a shady part of town when you're finding a lot of syringes and dime bags.  You always hear about an underground drug culture, but it's different when you actually directly encounter it.

When we were walking back for our lunch bag, we encountered a car chase.  A real one.  They were chasing somebody who had just committed a crime.  In fact, he had just killed a person and almost killed another.  We read about it in the paper the next day.  The chase went right by us twice, almost hitting us the second time.  Let me tell you, seeing three dozen marked and unmarked cop cars (plus two helicopters) all at once going passed you... that is something else.

Spending a day on a farm was a nice change of pace... an escape from our bunks in the CCNV and the bustle of city life.  By Thursday the weather was starting to get nicer, so raking up weeds for a couple hours and seeing cows was almost relaxing.  The farm we worked at, Clagett Farm in Upper Marlboro, MD, helps supply vegetables to the Capital Area Food Bank where we worked on Friday.  The 11 of us packed up over 30,000 lbs. of food plus who knows how many more boxes of hygiene products.  We worked so hard and did so many good things for people!

We also got to be tourists.  If you have the chance (which you actually do coming up, see below) to see the Holocaust Museum, don't miss it!  The monuments are also worth seeing.  The best is definitely spending a full week with a group of strangers doing great things!  Here's to Danielle, Meredith, Jakki, Christan, Tom, Ann, Yanique, Megan, Erin, and the studly one (Russell), plus Stan and Shea, for making my Spring Break amazing!  We have some pics on Facebook, so check them out!

A lot of other people did amazing trips on Spring Break.  Some were in West Virginia working at a camp for homeless kids, others were doing hurricane relief in Pensacola, FL, and a big group of IC students were in Louisiana to help with Katrina Relief, so find these people and ask about their amazing experiences!

A Quick Thank-You

Recently, some people with nothing better to do and obviously nothing else going for them decided to develop a campaign of harassment of me through emails and Facebook.  Several folks stood up for me and had the facebook group removed, and I just wanted to thank any who were a part of that.  If you have a serious concern with me or E-vents, please address it with me directly.  Don't be immature and harass me.  I certainly have better things to spend my time on and I would hope that you would too.

The First Annual Finger Lakes Tap Festival is soon approaching (March 31-April 2)!  Produced by Rhythm 'n Shoes (the IC Tap Dance Club) in collaboration with the Tap Legacy Foundation, Inc, the festival will feature five world-renowned guest artists.  Registration is $20.  To register online and get more information, visit http://www.fingerlakestapfestival.com.

Hillel is sponsoring a special educational tour to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum on Monday, March 27.  The bus will leave Sunday at midnight and return to Ithaca by Monday at midnight.  The cost is $10 and open to all.  To reserve a seat, contact Michael Faber at 274-3323 or faber@ithaca.edu.  [I had the opportunity to visit the Holocaust Museum while I was on Spring Break and it was really a moving experience.  If you can spare the Monday, I highly recommend taking this trip!]

Vote now for the "Out of the Closet and Onto the Screen" film festival!  The day-long festival, held on April 1st, will feature the most popular offerings of the Out of the Closet series.  This is a great chance to see films you missed this year!  Vote now for your favorites at http://www.surveymonkey.com/s.asp?u=867511742748. 

Form your team and sign up for the Relay for Life, to be held on April 1!  Let's do our best to out-fundraise Cornell!  Everything's online!  Check it out at http://www.acsevents.org/relay/ny/ithacacollege.

Volunteers are need for the Relay for Life!  If you'd be interested in helping out at all throughout the evening, contact Laura Teeter at lteeter1@ithaca.edu to let her know when you can help and what you're interested in helping with (set-up, registration, food, clean-up).

Sign up in the Fitness Center for a White Water Rafting Trip to be held on April 1st on the Lehigh River.  Cost is $50 which includes transportation.  Email ARC@ithaca.edu for more info.

Anthony Rapp will be speaking on campus on April 2nd at 8:00 PM.  He is best known for the role of Mark in Rent.  Get your tickets now!

Apply today for the experience of a lifetime and become the 06-08 Student Trustee!  The Student Trustee is the sole student member of the Board of Trustees, whose duties include setting tuition prices, approving and monitoring college funds and investments, employing the president, faculty tenure and promotion, and overseeing new building projects.  The Student Trustee also serves as an ex-officio member of the Student Government Association and on other campus committees.  For more information, stop by the Student Activities Center (3rd floor Campus Center), email studenttru@ithaca.edu, or call Raphael Golberstein at 274-3084.  Applications are available in the SAC or online at http://www.ithaca.edu/sga/docs/forms until April 3rd.

ICES, the Ithaca College Environmental Society, is hosting an Open Mic night on April 18th.  Email ablock1@ithaca.edu to sign up!

The position of Student Director for the Ithaca College Board of Alumni is now available.  The person in this position serves as a liaison for the Board, giving input and feedback on student life on campus.  It's a great way to network with alumni and looks great on resume.  It's a relatively easy time commitment, with only three weekend meetings a year and a few conference calls.  If you're interested in the position, contact Nicole Schmunk, the current director, at nschmun1@ithaca.edu or Graham Stewart, Director of Alumni Affairs, at stewart@ithaca.edu.  The application requires a resume and a cover letter.

Sign up now for the April 22nd Hole-In-One Weekend Golf Tournament.  Get more info at www.ithaca.edu/icgolf.

Contribute now to the Journal of Race, Culture, Gender, and Ethnicity.  Send your writing to icjournal@yahoo.com.

The Deadline List:

March 24th - Apply to volunteer for Senior Week.  Volunteers will get to stay through the week after finals and help manage all the events of Senior Week.  Pick up an application in the SAC (3rd Floor Campus Center).

March 24th - Apply to be a Student Leadership Consultant for next year!  You'll get to work event management, team building, peer advising, multimedia design, training and development, leadership development, community service, and more!  Details are available in the CSLI (3rd floor Campus Center).

March 24th - Sign up for a 64-player Horse Tournament to be held April 2nd.  There are prizes for the final four in the competition!

March 31st - Applications are now available for Fitness Center Personal Trainers.  Learn more about the position online at http://www.ithaca.edu/intercom/article.php/20060315093751707.

April 7th - Want to lead campus tours, meet prospective students, and participate in Admissions events?  Apply to join the President's Host Committee!  Applications are now available in the Office of Admissions (Job Hall).  Contact Cheryl Horihan at chorihan@ithaca.edu or 274-3124 for more information.

April 7th - Apply to be a Community Plunge Team Leader!  This is a great way to meet new first-year students and do some service for the Community!  Applications are available in the Center for Student Leadership and Involvement (CSLI - 3rd Floor Campus Center).

April 14th - If you missed out on the spring RA hiring process, you have a second chance!  Pick up an application in the Office of Residential Life and turn it in now!
Zack's Favorites:

Who are Zack's favorite members of IC a cappella groups?

Hopefully, all members of Ithacappella, Premium Blend, and Voicestream realize that I adore them and their hard work to create great music.  The use of this question in Zack's Favorites is merely to function as a cheap plug for something that otherwise wouldn't be listed in E-vents.

Okay, I'll admit it.  I have always had a huge crush on Gavin Sidebottom from Ithacappella.  Don't lie, you have too.  Even you straight guys, fess up.  He's gorgeous and so is his voice, and that's all there is to it.  You know who else is adorable and a great singer?  Laura Betinis from Premium Blend.  Without a doubt, those two are probably my favorite members of a cappella groups here at IC.  (Don't worry, I like A.J. too.)  But yeah, Gavin and Laura.

Do you know who I'm talking about?  If you've been to Ithacappella or Premium Blend concerts before you probably do.  If you don't, you should come to Muller Chapel this Saturday (3/25) at 7:00 PM.  Gavin Sidebottom and Laura Betinis both happen to be Voice Minors and they're doing a recital together.  There will be classical and pop stuff, so all will be able to enjoy it.  Like all recitals by students in the musical, it's totally free and there are no tickets.  Oh yeah, and did I mention I'll be taking a little break from Violet to play in it?  It should be a good time!  See you there.

*End Cheap/Cheesy Plug*

Tales From Bob's House

Episode Whatever - Man Knitting

In Bob's House over the past few months, one of our residents has set a new trend: man knitting.  Dan, aka Old Man Dan aka the Hammer aka Big Guy, has mastered the trade.  Thanks to the wonderful teachings of the master knitter, Alyssa of the distant Terrace, the Hammer has crossed boundaries few men have.  In doing so he has been able to maintain a proper testosterone balance.  While watching the many sports throughout the winter, he has knitted many a scarf.  Oh, and by the way ladies, he, like the other manly men of Terrace 4, is single and looking... you may just get a man-scarf out of the deal.

Valediction:

Take a little time this week and remember all the things you're so lucky to have, especially a home here at Ithaca College.

Home, the spot of earth supremely blest,
A dearer, sweeter spot than all the rest.
                               --Robert Montgomery

Have a great week everybody!  Pizzout!

--ZackFord, The E-vents Guy
